tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship."
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: he sang to Yahweh the words of this song
tn.text: "he sang this song to Yahweh"

tn.ref: on the day that Yahweh rescued him
tn.text: "after Yahweh had rescued him"
Here "hand" stands for the power of Saul. AT: "from Saul's power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock. The word "rock" is a picture of a safe place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the words "rock" and "fortress" share similar meanings and emphasize that Yahweh provides safety from enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to him for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my shield, the horn of my salvation, and my stronghold
tn.text: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a "shield," "the horn" of his salvation, and his "stronghold." Yahweh is the one who protects him from harm. Here a similar idea is repeated three ways for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will be saved from my enemies
tn.text: "I will be rescued from my enemies"

tn.ref: The cords of death surrounded me
tn.text: David speaks of death as if it were a person who could capture him and bind him with ropes. AT: "I was about to be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
David is as helpless as if he were being carried away by a rushing flood of waters. AT: "I felt completely helpless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The cords of Sheol surrounded me; the snares of death trapped me
tn.text: Here "Sheol," the place of the dead, and "death" are spoken of as if they were people who could surround and trap him. These two clauses have similar meanings and the idea is repeated for emphasis. AT: "I felt trapped and thought I was going to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"In my great need" or "In my despair"

tn.ref: my call for help went into his presence
tn.text: Here David speaks of his "call for help" as if it were a person who could come into the presence of Yahweh. AT: "I prayed to him" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here David speaks of how Yahweh heard his cry for help. The idea is repeated for emphasis. AT: "he heard my appeal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Then the earth ... shaken because God was angry
tn.text: God's being angry is spoken of as if the there was a terrible earthquake. AT: "God was so angry that it was as if the earth ... shaken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The words "shook" and "trembled" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how greatly the earth shook. AT: "the land moved back and forth" or "the ground moved up and down" or "there was a violent earthquake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the foundations of the mountains also trembled and were shaken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the foundations of the mountains also trembled and shook" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Smoke went up from out of his nostrils ... Coals were ignited by it
tn.text: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were breathing fire. This is a picture of how angry God was. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: blazing fire came out of his mouth. Coals were ignited by it
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "blazing fire came out of his mouth and ignited coals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "He" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: thick darkness was under his feet
tn.text: Though Yahweh does not actually have feet, the Psalmist gives him human characteristics. AT: "thick darkness was beneath him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here the Psalmist speaks of the wind as if it had wings like an angel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the words "He" and "him" refer to Yahweh.
Here darkness is spoken of as if it were a tent. AT: "He made darkness a covering" or "He made darkness a hiding place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"clouds heavy with rain" or "thick, dark rainclouds"
"stones made of ice"
Yahweh's voice sounded like thunder. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"the Most High" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies ... lightning bolts dispersed them
tn.text: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies
tn.text: Here lighting strikes are being spoken of as if they were arrows (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"sent them in different directions"
The writer continues to speak of Yaweh's great power.

tn.ref: Then the water channels appeared; the foundations of the world were exposed
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Then the water channels appeared and the bottom of the ocean became visible; you exposed the foundations of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: at the blast of the breath of your nostrils
tn.text: Though God does not have human physical characteristics as described here, this pictures his mighty strength. The wind is spoken of here as if it came as a mighty blast from God's nostrils. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He reached down ... he took hold ... He pulled me
tn.text: The word "He" in these verses refers to Yahweh.
Here the Psalmist speaks of the dangers of his enemies as if they were huge waves or forceful waters, from which Yahweh has rescued him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "They" refers to the strong enemies in verse 17.

tn.ref: They came against me on the day of my distress but Yahweh was my support
tn.text: The word "distress" describes the condition of one who has many troubles.  AT: "Strong enemies attacked me on a day when I had many troubles, but Yahweh protected me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here to possess "clean hands" means that one is innocent of wrongdoing. AT: "all my actions were right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I have kept the ways of Yahweh
tn.text: The laws of Yahweh are spoken of as if they were the paths on which one should walk. AT: "I have obeyed Yahweh's laws" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: have not wickedly turned away from my God
tn.text: Here being wicked is spoken of as if one left the right path and took the wrong path. AT: "have not done wickedly by turning away from my God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For all his righteous decrees ... I have not turned away from them
tn.text: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"have guided me" or "I have remembered"

tn.ref: I have also been innocent ... I have kept myself from sin
tn.text: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"innocent according to him"

tn.ref: I have kept myself from sin
tn.text: "I have not sinned"

To have "clean hands" means that one is innocent of wrongdoing. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:020|18:20]]: AT: "all my actions were right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to God's presence. AT: "before him" or "according to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The writer speaks to Yahweh.

Here "faithful" means to do what God commands one to do. You can state this clearly. AT: "to those who faithfully obey your commandments" or "to those who faithfully do your covenant" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: to a man who is blameless ... you show yourself pure
tn.text: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you are clever toward anyone who is twisted
tn.text: "you outwit anyone who is not honest"
"you humiliate"
This idiom refers to those who are proud. AT: "who are proud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: For you give light to my lamp; Yahweh my God lights up my darkness
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh's presence as if he were a light. These clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: For by you I can run over a barricade
tn.text: "For with your help I can cross any obstacle"

tn.ref: He is a shield to everyone who takes refuge in him
tn.text: A shield protects a soldier. David speaks as if God were a shield protecting him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:003:003|3:3]]. AT: "You, Yahweh, protect like a shield everyone who takes refuge in you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For who is God except Yahweh? Who is a rock except our God?
tn.text: The implied answer is no one. AT: "Only Yahweh is God! Only our God is a rock!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock that he could climb to get away from his enemies. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:002|18:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: puts strength on me like a belt
tn.text: God gives strength to David as if it were a piece of clothing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: places the blameless person on his path
tn.text: Here David speaks of living a life that is pleasing to God as if he were being placed on the right path. AT: "causes the blameless person to live a righteous life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to enabling a person to run fast. AT: "makes me run very fast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: like a deer and places me on the heights
tn.text: The deer is especially quick and stable in the mountains. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here "my hands" refers to the person. AT: "He trains me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to the person. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here the writer speaks of God's protection as if it were a shield. The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated with the verb "save." AT: "your protection and saved me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Both of these terms are metonyms that represent God himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: a wide place for my feet beneath me
tn.text: The writer speaks of the safety that God has provided as if it were a wide place for him to stand . AT: "a safe place for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "my feet" refers to the person. The writer refers to the safety of God's protection as if he were standing on a place where he will not slip or fall. AT: "I have not slipped" or "I am doing well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I crushed them" or "I broke them to pieces"
"unable to stand"

tn.ref: they have fallen under my feet
tn.text: This idiom means the Psalmist has defeated his enemies. AT: "I have defeated all of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: put strength on me like a belt
tn.text: The Psalmist says that Yahweh has given him strength that surrounds and supports him like a belt. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:030|18:32]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here the Psalmist speaks of the defeat of his enemies as if he were standing on them. AT: "you defeat for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: those who rise up against me
tn.text: This refers to those who oppose the Psalmist. AT: "those who are my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the back of my enemies' necks
tn.text: This represents victory over one's enemies. AT: "the victory over my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I annihilated those who hated me
tn.text: "I defeated those who hated me" or "I destroyed completely those who hated me"

tn.ref: but he did not answer them
tn.text: This means Yahweh did not provide any help. AT: "but he did not help them" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I beat them into fine pieces like dust before the wind
tn.text: The psalmists enemies are compared to dust to show how defeated they are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: I threw them out like mud in the streets
tn.text: The psalmist's enemies are compared to mud in the streets to show how defeated they are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"disagreements" or "arguments"

tn.ref: have made me the head over nations
tn.text: Here "head" represents the ruler. AT: "appointed me to be the ruler over many nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God forced foreigners to bow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Here "trembling" shows that they were very afraid. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "foreigners came shaking, showing that they were very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he is my rock and he should be praised" or "may people praise my rock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Here the writer speaks of Yahweh's protection as if he were a rock that prevented his enemies from reaching him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:002|18:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: May the God of my salvation be exalted
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May people exalt the God of my salvation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that it is God who has rescued him. AT: "the God who rescued me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the God who executes vengeance for me
tn.text: To "execute vengeance" means to punish people for their evil actions. AT: "the God who punishes people for the evil things they have done to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has set me free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Yahweh's protection of the writer is spoken of as if he lifted the writer up so high that his enemies could not reach him to harm him. AT: "you put me in a safe place high above" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"who attacked me" or "who rebelled against me"
"cruel men" or "savage men"
Here the writer means that he will give thanks to Yahweh so that all people will hear of Yahweh's greatness. AT: "so all the nations will hear about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "name" represents God himself. AT: "in honor of your name" or "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
By using the words "his king," David is referring to himself as king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: he shows his covenant loyalty to his anointed one ... to his descendants forever
tn.text: "he faithfully loves me as he promised in his covenant, and he will love my descendants forever"
